column52: SART11[SART1]. Instability of Situation   How changeable is the situation? Is the situation highly unstable and likely to change suddenly (High) or is it very stable and straightforward (Low)?  []
column53: SART21[SART2]. Complexity of Situation   How complicated is the situation? Is it complex with many interrelated components (High) or is it simple and straightforward (Low)?  []
column54: SART31[SART3]. Variability of Situation   How many variables are changing within the situation? Are there a large number of factors varying (High) or are there very few variables changing (Low)?  []
column55: SART41[SART4]. Arousal   How aroused are you in the situation? Are you alert and ready for activity (High) or do you have a low degree of alertness (Low)?  []
column56: SART51[SART5]. Concentration of Attention   How much are you concentrating on the situation? Are you concentrating on many aspects of the situation (High) or focussed on only one (Low)?  []
column57: distractor1[SART5]. Examination of Attention  Please select the first option.  []
column58: SART61[SART6]. Division of Attention   How much is your attention divided in the situation? Are you concentrating on many aspects of the situation (High) or focussed on only one (Low)?  []
column59: SART71[SART7]. Spare Mental Capacity   How much mental capacity do you have to spare in the situation? Do you have sufficient to attend to many variables (High) or nothing to spare at all (Low)?  []
column60: SART81[SART8]. Information Quantity   How much information have you gained about the situation? Have you received and understood a great deal of knowledge (High) or very little (Low)?  []
column61: SART91[SART9]. Information Quality  How good/accurate/of value was the information provided? Was it accessible, usable, and accurate (High) or difficult to obtain and inaccurate (Low)?  []
column62: SART101[SART10]. Familiarity with Situation   How familiar are you with the situation? Do you have a great deal of relevant experience (High) or is it a new situation (Low)?  []

column77: ImprovementVis. Regarding the autonomous vehicle that you have been driving virtually for the last few days:  Is there a way(s) to further improve your sense of safety in this vehicle? If so, please describe these option(s) here.

column79: behaviorOpen. How do you think autonomous vehicles will change people's behavior?

column86: feedback. Here, you can give open feedback regarding concerns, improvement proposals, and other thoughts.

column77: See more driving where the pedestrian crosses without a crosswalk and the vehicle has to react
column78: I loved the morning and evening drives, maybe make the coloring of objects, pedestrians more visible
column79: They will feel safer and less drunk driving accidents or accidents in general
column86: this was interesting

column77: Make the pedestrian detection feature more accurate. Right now, the pedestrian detection feature is useless. In 98% of cases it inaccurately labeled pedestrian intentions. I had to look at the scene and evaluate for myself what the pedestrians were doing and what I thought they were going to do. I could not rely on the autonomous car's assessment.
column78: The bad thing that stands out to me is the aforementioned pedestrian intention accuracy. I was particularly impressed with how the car handled turns where the lane was not marked in the middle of the intersection, and how it handled narrow streets with oncoming traffic. In those instances the car was able to stay in the correct lane with enough room for oncoming traffic. I would like to see where the car is intending to go, perhaps with a dotted line extended into the street in front of me. That way, I can tell if the car's assessment of the scenario is safe or not.
column79: I think more people will zone out while driving. I think people who are unable to drive due to seizures or other factors will be able to rely on a car more often. I am worried that it will negatively affect pedestrian behavior as pedestrians try to anticipate what the car is going to do.
column86: In terms of this survey: There were some problems with the survey. One of the questions, the scale was labeled in German and I had to use Google translate to find out what it meant. Additionally, it would have been helpful to see a reminder of what the different color highlights meant in the car video. That information only showed the very first time I did this survey. In the 5 subsequent occasions, I had to rely on my memory for what each color meant. This was particularly tricky when it came to pedestrians, since the color of the icon above their heads changed a lot.

I do think that it drove pretty well compared to what I expected though.

column77: I would say to have it a little more aware of its surroundings. At times the automated driving made some sketchy decisions but, overall it drove very well. It could you better awareness of what pedestrians are going to do as to I feel like those are where it struggled at times.

column78: I think having a distinct color for bikes and mopeds would be nice, something like purple. Also, it seems that city lights are mistaken for signs in the distance.
column79: I think it's going to make the roadways safer and it's going to save a lot of lives doing so. It will also free up time for other activities you could do while commuting.

column77: The vehicle from my point of view seems extremely safe, always driving the correct speed limit which is something not all us humans can say. I believe in many ways its already safer then how I personally drive my vehicle. I can only recommend working on the current module or setup to improve it further in detecting pedestrians and other cars. Its already safe as it is though but as time progresses I suppose it will only get better.
column78: I at times believed there were to many visuals. It wasn't bad but after awhile it would give me a headache, I am assuming this is how we see the world inside a automated vehicle because I have never been in one. If this is not the case then I believe the visuals were perfect for the vehicle to understand what is around it and to be safe with the people inside. I would like to see a automated vehicle that had both these visuals and a option to turn it off. Like, it would be pretty cool to be inside a car that had a front windshield displaying what the vehicle saw. I dont think its like that but would be cool.
column79: I think it will give me people to much relaxation. I could see myself falling asleep early in the morning on my commute to work. I dont see myself falling asleep during the first few months of owning such a vehicle but after awhile getting comfortable and feeling 100 percent safe I could see myself dazing off a bit. Having this feature would be amazing but the price would not be amazing. So over all I think automated vehicles is a bonus to life. Its a great thing to have. I would definitely opt for the vehicle that has both on and off automated driving. I always believed in the future automated vehicles would be the thing.
column86: Its been a blast watching the world from a automated vehicles point of view. Its amazing to me that technology has gone this far. I dont know if we have this type of technology in the USA. I know Tesla has some automated vehicles but honestly I do not see them much. Thank you again its been a blast these last few days! Very fun!

column79: Well, it is a nice leisurely ride opportunity, but I feel like many people will take this for granted on the freeway or even while they are sleeping during the ride. It can be dangerous, but it depends entirely on the person who utilizes the autonomous driving system.

column79: It'll change the transit landscape completely. I think making transport more accessible to people has the potential to be paradigm shifting as far as behavior goes, in many ways I can't even really comprehend.
column86: I think the technology will just have to continue to be developed, I don't believe it's there yet from what I've seen, it's an incredibly difficult task but I believe it'll be there sooner than later.

column78: i thought the visualizations painted a perfect picture of what it felt like being inside of the automation. Bad was the detection of oedestrians that weren't visible. It made me have anxiety seeing those signals.

column86: The last question on the page prior to this one is in German. I had to use google translate to translate what "stimme gar nicht zu" meant in english.

column77: I believe that this vehicle has been driving safely, however as someone who has mainly driven in Canada I am not entirely sure if there are road rules that differ that I would be unaware of here
column78: The pedestrian intention tagging is occasionally poor, with tags appearing where no pedestrians are present, and tags often being incorrect
column79: I believe that people may be more anxious about autonomous vehicles until a significant amount are present, as they may be perceived to be untrustworthy when dealing with a majority of human drivers

column77: I would want to know that I can immediately take over the wheel at any time to help correct the vehicle when it does incorrect things. For example, in this video, the car continued driving when there was a *red* street light. I would want to be able to quickly grab the wheel, put my foot on the break, to keep the car from driving forward on its own.  But I have to say, that if I had been in this car, I would have panicked due to the car not stopping for the red light.
column78: I liked two things a lot -- 1.) The yellow highlight over   street signs. I've literally said to people before that I think street signs need to be a more bold color (white sometimes gets missed!) so that they are  harder to miss. Separately, I liked the dark blue highlight for people who are in the street. The streets shown in the videos are much narrower than I am used to (our streets are typically wider), so it made me nervous when seeing people do things like jump over the concrete median on such a narrow street, and so near to "my" car, with very little room to spare. The light blue and dark blue highlights over the people jumping over the concrete median made them stand out and were much more noticeable to me.   CHANGE: I think I would change the blue hightlight over all the other vehicles.  All the different highlights were really hard for me to get used to because it made so many more things stand out to me, but the vehicles being highlighted really was too much for me, on top of the other different highlight colors.  Maybe make the vehicles highlighted ONLY when you are in a high-crash type situation, like maybe when you are changing lanes. The cars around you should then be highlighted when you turn your turn signal on, so that you can then make sure you don't hit another car that you might not see when changing lanes.
column79: I think a large number of people will be jerks and do something in autonomous vehicles that makes it so that they don't pay attention to the road at all. For example, here in the US, we have already had situations where someone got into the back seat of the car and laid down to sleep while their self-driving car was driving down the road. Another news article pointed out that a guy was busy watching pornography while his autonomous car was driving for him.  For someone like ME, however; I think it will change my behavior IF we can get to the point where these types of cars are more safe than human drivers. It will help me to feel more safe. I don't feel like we are at that point yet. I would them be MORE willing to drive longer distances and in situations where I typically don't drive because I feel unsafe (our  busy freeways in my city, would be one example).
column86: Very interesting study! Thank you. :)

If I could change anything, I would like the predictions to improve, but it's not a huge deal.
column79: I think it will lead to less accidents in the future, and reduce the amount of "road-rage". It will also reduce the amount of mental strain from driving.

column78:
- the perception in the daytime was very pleasent. It detected the vehicles and such pretty good. I would improve the detection at night time. 
- very bad was the intentions of the pedestrians. They were changing to often and it was more irratating than helpful. also the signs of the pedestrians were jumping around crazy at night
column79: i think it would make the driving experience a lot more pleasant and less stressful, when there is a lot of traffic. I think people will use the individual transportation more often, because it is more accessible and easier to use.

column77: I think having a gps type screen showing the route the vehicle is headed would be really useful.  I think the detection of people really needs to be worked on so that it is 100% solid.
column78: At first, the visualizations were extremely overwhelming.  After a while I got used to it, but the constant flickering of the icons above the pedestrians heads was very annoying, distracting, and incorrect more often than not.
column79: I think that people will multitask in the car a lot more with the use of autonomous vehicles.

column77: I can't think of anything else.
column78: I thought the way that the visuals kept blinking was somewhat distracting. I thought it was good how they pointed out all the cars and pedestrians.
column79: I think they will make people less aware of  what's going on outside of their vehicles.

column77: It seems like the vehicle took the traffic light or lack there of as priority over pedestrians intentions.  There was a moment where the vehicle made a right turn when there was no light as pedestrians were beginning to cross.  Also it seems like the vehicle was moving too close to the object in front of it.  In some instances it was so far up I couldn't tell what color the traffic light was and was weary of it going on red.
column78: The assigned colors were good because it created a clear distinction of the different entities that the vehicle had to identify.  The pedestrian intentions weren't always accurate and it sometimes designated a bike as a pedestrian even though there was no body riding it.  I would probably create a wider camera view because in some instances during a red traffic light the vehicle would move too far up past the line to where I couldn't see what color the traffic light was.
column79: I think there will come a point where it will mostly be autonomous vehicles on the road.  If the majority on the road is autonomous there will be a better sense of safety as opposed to only a few on the road because there are some cases on the road that logic will not come into play, like adjusting your speed to a car or pedestrians that may not be following the traffic rules or in some rural areas where traffic signs and roads aren't as defined.
column86: I think there we're too early in the stages of autonomous vehicles and not enough out there that any minor error can cause large implications.  It would almost make sense to roll out a significant amount of vehicles targeting certain regions and then expand outwards from there.  The mixture of autonomous and non-autonomous driving can cause a lot of issues especially this early in the development.

column77: I think the mechanisms of the autonomous vehicle fulfill my sense of safety.
column78: I liked the shade of the colors. I also thought it was to have the action above the head of people.
column79: I think autonomous vehicles will allow people to be more relaxed in vehicles and less aware.

column77: I think the car gets really close to other cars at stops and does not slow down for pedestrians. I think there are areas in which the car needs improvement.
column78: The pedestrian detection is awful at night and it struggles to determine a pedestrians intentions at all times. I would just use detection of pedestrians and not their decision to walk or not it gets to confusing. I would also add a night mode to help detect things better.
column79: I think more people like them but I think they are a risk and this simulation shows that they are a risk and need improvement.

column86: There were no emergency maneuvers that the car had to perform.  Also, none of the cars were aggressive driving, disobeying signals, or not following all traffic rules for the car to react to.

column78: I think it was good.  But I would have liked to see what would happen if a dog, child or adult just darted into the road
column79: I think it will show us that autonomous vehicles are pretty safe.

column77: Overall I am very pleased with the experience. I do feel that occasionally the vehicle does over predict pedestrians, especially when there are people walking near highly reflective glass buildings.
column78:
I still at times find the detection of street signs coloring a bit too intense as it makes seeing the original sign color hard at a quick glance. I also find the flickering of the intention of pedestrians can be very distracting in certain lighting conditions. 

It would be nice to have some indication of the pathing it intends to take visible to myself so that I could be better aware of any upcoming obstacles. That being said, I would feel comfortable sitting in the vehicle though.
column79: I think they will be good overall, but I do worry about people forgetting how to drive and how that will make the roads even more dangerous if people get in a normal vehicle on occasion.
column86: I do feel that each area will need to do testing as the car will have to learn about local pathing and any rules that are state exclusive. It would be interesting to see how the vehicle did if it was driving from say NJ into NYC.
